title-group.article-title: Postpartum Opioid-Related Mortality in Publicly Insured Patients

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Pharmacoepidemiology and Pharmacoeconomics, Department of Medicine, Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA
2Department of Epidemiology, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA
3Departments of International Health and Gynecology and Obstetrics, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD
4Division of Alcohol, Drugs, and Addiction, McLean Hospital, Belmont, MA
5Department of Psychiatry, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA
6Division of Maternal-Fetal Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Boston, MA
7UNC Horizons and Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC
8Department of Anesthesiology, Perioperative and Pain Medicine, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Elizabeth A Suarez, Division of Pharmacoepidemiology and Pharmacoeconomics, Brigham and Women’s Hospital & Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, h4p@bwh.harvard.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To assess the incidence and risk factors for postpartum opioid overdose death and describe other causes of postpartum death in individuals with opioid use disorder.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We conducted a cohort study using healthcare utilization data from the Medicaid Analytic eXtract (MAX) linked to the National Death Index in the US from 2006–2013. All pregnant individuals with live births or stillbirths and continuous enrollment for 3 months prior to delivery were eligible, including 4,972,061 deliveries. A sub-cohort with record of opioid use disorder in the 3 months prior to delivery was identified. We estimated the cumulative incidence of death occurring between delivery and 1 year postpartum among all individuals and individuals with opioid use disorder. Risk factors for opioid overdose death were assessed using odds ratios and descriptive statistics, including demographics, health care utilization, obstetric conditions, comorbidities, and medications.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The incidence of postpartum opioid overdose death per 100,000 deliveries was 5.4 (95% CI 4.5–6.4) among all individuals and 118 (95% CI 84–163 among individuals with opioid use disorder. Individuals with opioid use disorder had a 6-fold higher incidence of all-cause postpartum death than all individuals. Common causes of death in individuals with opioid use disorder were other drug- and alcohol related (47 per 100,000), suicide (26 per 100,000), and other injuries including accidents and falls (33 per 100,000). Risk factors strongly associated with postpartum opioid overdose death included mental health and other substance use disorders. Among patients with opioid use disorder, postpartum use of medication to treat opioid use disorder was associated with 60% lower odds of opioid overdose death (OR 0.4, 95% CI 0.1–0.9).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Postpartum individuals with opioid use disorder have a high incidence of postpartum opioid overdose death and other preventable deaths including non-opioid substance-related injuries, accidents, and suicide. Use of medications for opioid use disorder is strongly associated with lower opioid-related mortality.

abstract.title: Précis:
abstract.p: Pregnant individuals with opioid use disorder have a high incidence of postpartum death due to opioid overdose, other substance-related injuries, accidents, and suicide.
